title: 107_hr1098
content: The "Maritime Policy Improvement Act of 2001" includes provisions such as the naming of vessels, expansion of the American Merchant Marine Memorial Wall of Honor, discharge of agricultural cargo residue, recording and discharging maritime liens, and various certificates of documentation for vessels. The Congress acknowledges the significant role of the United States Merchant Marine in various wars, including serving as the Nation's first navy, contributing to the victory in World War II, and being praised as the "Fourth Arm of Defense" by President Franklin D. Roosevelt. Over 250,000 men and women served in the Merchant Marine during World War II, facing dangers from submarines, mines, and other threats. During World War II, the United States Merchant Marine had over 250,000 members who faced dangers from submarines, mines, and other threats. At least 6,830 members were killed at sea, 11,000 were wounded, and 604 were taken prisoner. 1 in 32 members died in the line of duty, the highest percentage among all U.S. armed services. The Merchant Marine continues to serve the U.S. promoting freedom. The United States Merchant Marine had a high percentage of war-related deaths during World War II, with over 6,830 members killed at sea. The Merchant Marine continues to serve the U.S. and promote freedom. The Secretary of Transportation may provide grants for constructing an addition to the American Merchant Marine Memorial Wall of Honor in California. SEC. 5. DISCHARGE OF AGRICULTURAL CARGO RESIDUE. The discharge of agricultural cargo residue from a vessel shall be governed by the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships. SEC. 6. RECORDING AND DISCHARGING MARITIME LIENS. Section 31343 of title 46, United States Code is amended to allow for the recording and discharging of liens on documented vessels. The Secretary must record a notice complying with the section if a declaration is filed with the notice stating the information is true and correct. The amendment to section 31343 of title 46, United States Code allows for the recording and discharging of liens on documented vessels. A declaration must be filed with the notice, stating the information is true and correct. The declaration must be signed by the authorized official if the person is not an individual. Subsection (c) is amended to address full and final discharge of the indebtedness that is the basis for a notice of claim of lien. The amendment to section 31343 of title 46, United States Code allows for the recording and discharging of liens on documented vessels. A declaration must be filed with the notice, signed by the authorized official if the person is not an individual. Subsection (c) is amended to address full and final discharge of the indebtedness that is the basis for a notice of claim of lien. The district courts have jurisdiction over civil actions related to vessel liens. The amendment to section 31343 of title 46, United States Code allows for the recording and discharging of liens on documented vessels. Venue for civil actions related to vessel liens is determined by where the vessel is found, where the claimant resides, or where the notice of claim of lien is recorded. A notice of claim of lien expires 3 years after the specified date. The law pertaining to maritime liens, remedies, and defenses remains unchanged. The amendment allows for recording and discharging liens on vessels. Notice requirements for claims of liens are updated, and approval for surrendering vessel documentation is clarified. Additionally, a technical correction is made to the Shipping Act. The amendment allows for recording and discharging liens on vessels over 1,000 gross tons. A technical correction is made to the Shipping Act, with an effective date of July 1, 2002. The Secretary of Transportation will determine the tonnage measurement for the small passenger vessel R/V DAVIDSON for regulatory purposes. This measurement applies when the vessel complies with specific requirements. Additionally, there are provisions for miscellaneous certificates of documentation. The Secretary of Transportation may issue certificates of documentation for specific vessels for employment in the coastwise trade, bypassing certain regulations. The vessels include LOOKING GLASS, YANKEE, LUCKY DOG, ENTERPRIZE, M/V SANDPIPER, FRITHA, PUFFIN, VICTORY OF BURNHAM, R'ADVENTURE II, ANTJA, and SKIMMER. The vessels listed for certificates of documentation include TOKEENA, DOUBLE EAGLE2, ENCOUNTER, AJ, BARGE 10, NOT A SHOT, PRIDE OF MANY, AMAZING GRACE, and SHEWHO. SEC. 9. EXEMPTION FOR VICTORY SHIPS. Amends Section 3302(l)(1) of title 46, United States Code to exempt the steamships SS Red Oak Victory and SS American Victory. SEC. 10. CERTIFICATE OF DOCUMENTATION FOR 3 BARGES. SEC. 10. CERTIFICATE OF DOCUMENTATION FOR 3 BARGES. The Secretary of Transportation may issue a certificate of documentation for employment in the coastwise trade for three specified vessels: the former Navy deck barge JIM, the former railroad car barge HUGH, and the former railroad car barge TOMMY. These vessels are limited to being used as floating platforms for launching fireworks. SEC. 11. The Secretary of Transportation will issue a certificate of documentation for the vessel EAGLE for coastwise trade if owned or chartered by a State entity, operated for specific purposes, and clearly identified. SEC. 12. Waiver for vessels in New World Challenge Race. SEC. 12. Waiver for vessels in New World Challenge Race allows 10 sailboats in the race to transport guests without payment until race completion or December 31, 2003. SEC. 13. Vessel ASPHALT COMMANDER may be transferred to a foreign registry or sold to a non-US citizen.
